questions.text: A mother brings her newborn baby to the clinic for evaluation. The baby has a penis, a scrotum with no testes, and no vagina . Genotype determination shows XX chromosomes . Which of the following is the most likely cause of this baby’s abnormalities ?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of a testosterone-secreting tumor in the mother’s adrenal gland/s

options.label: C
options.text: Abnormally high levels of LH in the maternal blood

options.label: D
options.text: Abnormally low levels of testosterone in the maternal blood

questions.correct_answer: B. The presence of a testosterone-secreting tumor in the mother’s adrenal gland/s
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Differences (disorders) of sex development (DSDs; formerly known as “intersex conditions”) are a group of congenital conditions characterized by the atypical development of chromosomal, gonadal, and/or phenotypic sex
  • ↳ The underlying genetic mutations can affect the number and function of sex chromosomes (e.g., in Turner syndrome), cause structural changes that influence the sensitivity of hormone receptors (e.g., androgen insensitivity syndrome), and alter the function of enzymes responsible for sex hormone synthesis (e.g., congenital adrenal hyperplasia).
  • ↳ Features vary depending on the specific disorder but may include the mismatch between sexual genotype and phenotype, reduced fertility or infertility, and organ malformations (e.g., cardiac abnormalities).
  • ↳ The discrepancy between sexual phenotype and genotype can cause difficulties in gender identification with considerable subsequent psychological distress.
  • ↳ DSD diagnosis is based on clinical features, evaluation of hormone levels, and genetic testing.
  • ↳ Differential diagnosis should consider other anomalies of the male and female genital tracts.
  • ↳ Treatment should be provided based on patient preference and sexual identification, and clinical necessity backed by strong ethical principles.
  • ↳ If treatment is necessary and/or desired, it follows a multidisciplinary approach involving hormone substitution and psychological counseling.
  • ↳ Gender affirmation surgery should only be performed if the patient requests the procedure and can provide informed consent.

questions.explanation:
Topic Bullous Impetigo
Definition Bullous impetigo is a superficial skin infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus bacteria. It is a form of impetigo characterized by the presence of fluid-filled blisters or bullae.
Causative Agent Staphylococcus aureus bacteria, particularly strains producing exfoliative toxins, are the main cause of Bullous Impetigo.
Mode of Transmission Bullous impetigo is highly contagious and can spread through direct contact with infected skin or items contaminated with the bacteria. It often affects children and infants.
Clinical Features - Development of large, painless, and flaccid blisters or bullae filled with clear or cloudy yellow fluid. The bullae are fragile and can rupture easily, leaving a red, raw area beneath.
  - Redness and irritation surrounding the blisters.
  - Itching or discomfort in the affected areas.
Sites of Occurrence Bullous impetigo commonly affects the trunk, diaper area (in infants), and areas with skin folds. It can also occur on the face, arms, and legs.
Diagnosis - Clinical examination: The appearance of bullae and the typical presentation help in diagnosing bullous impetigo.
  - Bacterial culture: A swab from the affected area may be taken to identify the causative bacteria and determine antibiotic sensitivity.
Treatment - Topical Antibiotics: Mild cases can often be treated with topical antibiotic ointments containing mupirocin or fusidic acid. The affected area should be kept clean and dry.
  - Oral Antibiotics: For more extensive or severe cases, oral antibiotics like dicloxacillin, cephalexin, or clindamycin may be prescribed. Treatment should continue for the full course as directed by the healthcare provider.
  - Warm Compress: Applying warm compresses to the affected area can help in the healing process.
  - Hygiene Measures: Good hygiene practices, such as frequent handwashing and avoiding close contact with infected individuals, can help prevent the spread of the infection.
Prognosis Bullous impetigo is generally a benign condition with a good prognosis when appropriately treated. However, complications, such as cellulitis or systemic infection, can occur if left untreated.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presented to the hospital with a lump in her breast. On examination, there is the presence of a dimpling sign. Mammography was performed by the physician. Which of the following is a characteristic of a Diagnostic test as compared to a Screening test?

options.text: Based on one criterion or cut-off point

options.label: D
options.text: Done on those with indications or sick

questions.correct_answer: D. Done on those with indications or sick
questions.explanation:
Screening test Diagnostic test
It is done on an apparently healthy individual It is done on those with indications or sick.
Applied to groups Applied to single patients: All diseases are considered in a diagnostic test
Test results are arbitrary and final Diagnosis is not final but modified in light of new evidence, diagnosis is the sum of all evidence.
Based on one criterion or cut-off point Based on evaluation of a number of symptoms, signs (e.g., diabetes), and laboratory findings.
Less accurate: Less expensive; Not a basis for treatment More accurate: More expensive; Used as a basis of treatment
The initiative comes from the investigator or agency providing care. The initiative comes from a patient with a complaint.

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased bilirubin production in the liver.

options.label: C
options.text: Bilirubin cannot be excreted from the liver.

options.label: D
options.text: Increased hemolysis of red blood cells.

questions.correct_answer: D. Increased hemolysis of red blood cells.
questions.explanation:
Type of Jaundice Causes Characteristics
Prehepatic Jaundice - Hemolysis (excessive breakdown of red blood cells) - Gilbert's syndrome (a genetic condition affecting bilirubin processing) - Increased unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin levels in the blood - Normal liver function
Hepatic Jaundice - Liver diseases (e.g., hepatitis, cirrhosis) - Medications/toxins that affect the liver - Infections - Alcoholic liver disease - Both unconjugated (indirect) and conjugated (direct) bilirubin levels may be elevated in the blood - Impaired liver function
Posthepatic Jaundice - Bile duct obstruction (e.g., gallstones, tumors, biliary atresia) - Pancreatic cancer - Choledocholithiasis (gallstones in the common bile duct) - Elevated conjugated (direct) bilirubin levels in the blood - Bile flow obstruction from the liver to the intestines

questions.correct_answer: B. The disease is confluent, there are no skip areas in the colon, and the rectum is involved
questions.explanation:
Ulcerative Colitis (UC)  
Wall involvement Mucosal and submucosal ulcers
Location Begins in the rectum and can extend proximally up to the cecum, the remainder of the GI tract is unaffected
Symptoms Left lower quadrant pain (rectum) with bloody diarrhea
Inflammation Crypt abscesses with neutrophils
Gross appearance Pseudopolyps; loss of haustra 
Complications Toxic megacolon and carcinoma (risk is based on the extent of colonic involvement and duration of disease, generally no a concern until >10 years of disease)

A 20-year-old woman gives a history of sharp pain in the lower abdomen for 2-3 days every month approximately 2 weeks before the menses. The most probable etiology for her pain is
questions.explanation:
Definition Mittelschmerz is a German word that means "middle pain." It refers to the sharp lower abdominal pain some women experience during ovulation.
Timing Mittelschmerz occurs around the middle of the menstrual cycle, typically 2 weeks before menstruation, coinciding with ovulation.
Cause The pain is caused by the release of a mature egg from the ovary during ovulation. The process can cause irritation and stretching of the ovarian tissue and surrounding structures.
Location The pain is usually felt on one side of the lower abdomen, corresponding to the side where the ovary is releasing the egg.
Nature of Pain The pain is often described as sharp or cramp-like and may last for a few minutes to a few hours.
Duration Mittelschmerz pain can occur intermittently over 2-3 days.
Frequency Mittelschmerz is typically experienced once per menstrual cycle.
Associated Symptoms Some women may experience other symptoms, such as light vaginal spotting or discharge, along with the pain.
Diagnosis The diagnosis of Mittelschmerz is usually based on the characteristic timing of the pain in relation to ovulation and the absence of other medical conditions.
Treatment Mittelschmerz is a normal and benign phenomenon and does not require specific treatment. However, over-the-counter pain relievers can be used for symptom relief if needed.
Management If the pain is severe or significantly impacts the woman's quality of life, she should discuss her symptoms with a healthcare provider for further evaluation and management.

Early Congenital syphilis Late Congenital syphilis
Appears within 2–6 weeks after birth.
  • Appears after 2 years of age when the baby is untreated.
  • Rhinitis or "snuffles".
  • Mucocutaneous lesions, rhagades (linear scars at the end of mouth).
  • Bone changes Osteochondritis, osteitis, and periostitis are detectable by an x-ray of long bones.
  • Hepatosplenomegaly.
  • Lymphadenopathy.
  • Anaemia, jaundice, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis.
  • Interstitial keratitis(occurs at 5–25 years of age).
  • CN VIII deafness.
  • Recurrent arthropathy.
  • Bilateral knee effusions - Clutton's joints.
  • Gummatous periostitis occurs at 5–20 years of age.
  • Classic stigmata - Hutchinson's teeth, "Mulberry" molars.
  • Saddle nose.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman, G2P0A1, is at 30 weeks gestation. Her fundal height measures 25cm. An obstetrical ultrasound examination reveals a 4 quadrant amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 4cm. Which of the following fetal conditions is associated with the finding?

A 30-year-old woman, Gravida 2, Para 2, at 38 weeks of gestation, presents in active labour. On examination, her contractions are regular, her cervix is 4 cm dilated, and she is 50 % effaced. The fetal head is at 0 stations. Which of the following is the fetal head diameter most likely engaged in this case?
questions.explanation:
Diameters Measurement In CM (Inches) Attitude Of The Head Presentation
1. Suboccipito-bregmatic 9.5 cm (3 ¾’’) Complete flexion Vertex
2. Suboccipito-frontal 10 cm Incomplete flexion Vertex
3. Occipito-frontal 11.5 cm Incomplete flexion Vertex
4. Mento-vertical 14 cm (5 ½”) Deflexed head/ military position Brow
5. Submento vertical 11.5 cm Incomplete extension Face
6.Submento-bregmatic 9.5 cm (3 ¾’’) Complete extension Face

Fetal Head Diameter Description Clinical Significance
Biparietal Diameter (BPD) - Distance between the two parietal bones of the fetal skull. - Important for measuring fetal head size during ultrasound.
    - Used to estimate gestational age and assess growth.
Occipitofrontal Diameter (OFD) - Distance between the occiput (back of the head) and the frontal bone (forehead). - Helps estimate fetal head size in different orientations.
    - Useful in cases of face or brow presentation.
Suboccipitobregmatic Diameter - Smallest diameter of the fetal head, from the suboccipital bregma to the anterior fontanelle. - Helpful in assessing the fetal head's engagement and descent through the birth canal.
    - Important in determining the fetal head's position in labor.
Anteroposterior Diameter (APD) - Distance from the anterior to the posterior aspect of the fetal head. - Measured during ultrasound to assess head size and position.
    - Relevant in cases of face presentation or occiput posterior position.
